guiding_thinkers: György Márkus, Hans Joas, John Dewey, G.H. Mead
description: Analyzes social life through creative action, technical normativity, and the constitutive role of material practice, critiquing the reduction of human activity to communication

assumptions: Human beings are fundamentally makers - homo faber precedes homo loquens
Technical activity has its own normativity not reducible to communicative reason
Creativity is a dimension of all action, not just exceptional moments
Tools and artifacts mediate between humans and world constitutively
Practice is prior to theory - understanding emerges from doing
Language is one form of symbolic mediation among others, not the master key
core_tensions: Work vs Communication - productive activity versus linguistic interaction
Technical vs Communicative Rationality - making things work versus reaching understanding
Creativity vs Routine - novel action versus habitual reproduction
Individual vs Social - personal creativity versus collective practices
scope_conditions: Applies to all forms of human activity, not just discourse
Requires attention to material practices and technical competence
Focus on situated action in concrete contexts

primary_entities: Praxis - purposive human activity transforming both world and actor
Technical Normativity - standards of correctness internal to material practices
Creative Action - action that generates genuinely new possibilities
Habit - embodied dispositions that enable and constrain action
Situation - the concrete context that calls forth and shapes action
relations: Tool Mediation - artifacts enabling and shaping human capacities
Skill Acquisition - embodied learning through practice
Problem-Response - action arising from problematic situations
Expressive Completion - action realizing inchoate impulses
levels_of_analysis: Bodily-practical - embodied skills and material engagement
Institutional-social - organized practices and collective action

change_mechanisms: Creative response - novel solutions to blocked action
Tool innovation - new artifacts enabling new practices
Habit transformation - reconstruction of settled dispositions
temporal_patterns: Skill development - from conscious effort to embodied mastery
Social learning - transmission and transformation of practices
transformation_processes: Reconstruction - reorganizing experience in response to problems
Democratic experimentalism - collective testing of social arrangements
Technical progress - development of productive capacities

key_concepts: Technical Normativity - standards governing whether practices achieve their aims
Creative Action - action not determined by prior conditions or rules
Situation - the problematic context calling forth inquiry and action
Objectivation - human capacities externalized in artifacts and institutions
Communicative Reification - false reduction of all reason to discourse
Means-End Holism - ends and means reciprocally constitute each other
analytical_methods: Genetic reconstruction - tracing how practices emerged and evolved
Situational analysis - understanding action in its concrete context
Technical critique - evaluating practices by their internal standards
Comparative pragmatics - examining different forms of practical reason
problem_diagnosis: Communicative reification - treating discourse as the only form of reason
Work denigration - devaluing productive activity relative to speech
Technical alienation - loss of understanding of how things work
Creativity suppression - social forms blocking novel action
ideal_state: Integrated praxis - unity of making, doing, and speaking
Technical democracy - shared control over productive processes
Creative society - institutions enabling rather than blocking novelty

trait_definitions.trait_description: Attention to purposive, transformative human activity
Standards internal to practices of making and doing
Focus on genuinely novel, non-determined action

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Treating all rationality as reducible to discourse or communication
critique_patterns.fix: Identify the technical-practical rationality in {activity} irreducible to {speech_act}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Ignoring or devaluing productive labor in analysis
Explaining action solely through prior causes or rule-following
critique_patterns.fix: Show how {action} involves creative response to {problematic_situation}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Treating tools and artifacts as neutral means

historical_context: Synthesizes classical pragmatism with Marxian praxis philosophy, developed particularly in Márkus's 'Language and Production'
